abstract.para: This document is the official user's guide to OmegaT, the free Computer Aided Translation tool. It also contains installation instructions.

chapter.title: Installing and Running OmegaT
chapter.para: OmegaT packages are available both in versions bundled with Java, and versions without it. Packages without Java rely on your having a &javaversionlong; installed system-wide. OmegaT 5.8.0 and later also support Java 11 Runtime Environment on any platforms.
Due to licencing considerations, the OmegaT team recommends the Java runtime Eclipse Temurin provided by the &preferedopenjdk;, but any Java 8 compatible runtime environment should work.

listitem.para: Standard: This edition is suitable for everyday use.
Developer: This is a cutting-edge edition containing the latest work in progress. It is more suitable for testing new features.

chapter.para: The download site is here. All the packages listed below are available from that site.

section.title: Windows
section.para: The simplest way to launch OmegaT is to execute the OmegaT.exe program. The options for the program start-up will be read from the OmegaT.l4J.ini file, which resides in the same folder as the exe file and which you can edit to reflect your setup. The following example for the INI file reserves 1 GB of memory, requests French as the user language and Canada as the country:

section.title: Linux
section.para: You can launch OmegaT from the command line with a script that includes start-up options. See for details.
You can also click on OmegaT.jar to launch it directly if the .jar extension is associated to the system Java launcher.
The package also provides a omegat.kaptn Kaptain script, which KDE users might find useful, as well as an OmegaT bash script that automatically launches the appropriate java command to run OmegaT.

section.title: macOS
section.para: Double-click on OmegaT.app or click on its location in the Dock.
To launch multiple instances of OmegaT.app, double-click the file OmegaT located in OmegaT.app/Contents/MacOS/.
Use the OmegaT.jar file located in OmegaT.app/Contents/MacOS/Java/ to launch OmegaT from the command line. See for details.
You can modify the behaviour of OmegaT.app by editing the Configuration.properties (OmegaT configuration) as well as the Info.plist (Java configuration) files located inside the OmegaT.app package.
To access the configuration files, right-click on OmegaT.app and select "Show Package Contents".
Configuration.properties is located in Contents/Resources/. Info.plist is located in Contents/.
Right-click on the file you want to modify and select your text editor of choice or cd there directly from the command line and open the files from the command line.
OmegaT's configuration is changed by modifying Configuration.properties.
For predefined options, remove the # before a parameter to enable it. For example, user.language=ja (without the #) will launch OmegaT with the user interface in Japanese.
The Java configuration is changed by modifying Info.plist.

For example, to change the amount of memory available uncomment the line <!-- <string>-Xmx6g</string> --> by removing the <!-- and -->. This will launch OmegaT with 6 GB of memory; change the 6g to the desired amount.

section.title: macOS Services
section.para: OmegaT.app can make use of macOS Services. You can also use AppleScript, Automator or Shortcuts to create Services or scripts that will automate frequent actions.

section.title: Other systems
section.para: Methods vary from one system to another, but in general, once OmegaT is installed, you can launch it directly from the command line. See for details. You can create a script that includes the desired command line launch parameters. If .jar files are properly associated with &javaversionlong; and your PATH settings are correct, you can also simply click (or double-click) on OmegaT.jar to launch it directly. Consult the documentation for your system for more information.

section.title: Upgrading and deleting OmegaT
section.para: OmegaT can tell you when a new version is available. See in the dialog for details.
The changes between your version and the current version are documented in the development site's change.txt file.

note.para: If you decide to install a new version, keep the following in mind:

listitem.para: OmegaT's preferences are stored in the configuration folder and will not be modified by the new version. See for details.

Projects that you have created in the past or are currently using will not be modified or deleted. OmegaT projects are not stored inside OmegaT. They are separate objects that have no physical connection to the OmegaT application itself.

Parameter files that are included in the downloaded OmegaT package (especially the OmegaT.l4J.ini for and the Configuration.properties and Info.plist files for packages) might be overwritten or deleted, so you may want to create a backup before upgrading, if you have been using these files to modify OmegaT's launch parameters.
The plugins and scripts folders might be overwritten, so you may want to create a backup before upgrading.

section.title: Install over an existing version
section.para: To do this, simply select the same installation folder as the existing installation when installing the new version. The "old" version of OmegaT will be overwritten, but settings made from the OmegaT interface will be retained in the various configurations folders (see above).

section.title: Install alongside an existing version
section.para: This will enable you to keep any number of versions side-by-side, which you may wish to do until you feel comfortable with the new version.

All the parameters located in the will be shared unless you specify a different configuration folder with the --config-dir=<path> option from the on the command line . All the parameters located in a will apply to that project regardless of which version of OmegaT opens it.

section.title: Delete OmegaT
section.para: Use your operating system's standard procedure to remove OmegaT. If you want to remove OmegaT completely, you will also have to delete the configuration folder.
If you performed a manual installation on Linux, you will have to manually delete the OmegaT folders in opt/, as well as the symlinks placed in /usr/local/bin/ by the installation script.

chapter.title: Learn to Use OmegaT in 15 Minutes!

section.title: OmegaT principles
section.para: OmegaT is a computer-assisted translation (CAT) tool that offers great flexibility and performance, as well as features beyond those of commercial offerings, even for beginning translators.

listitem.para: An OmegaT translation project consists of a folder that stores a number of resources in separate subfolders. Translators can easily modify the contents of the subfolders at any time during the translation simply by copying, moving or deleting files.

At a minimum, resources include at the minimum the project's translation memory, which is automatically upon project creation, and the files to translate. It can also include reference translation memories, glossaries, and other reference files.
Translators do not have to create a translation memory or associate one to a new project. OmegaT takes care of that automatically.

Translators can very easily reuse an existing project's translation memory by simply adding new translation files to the old project, or by copying the old translation memory to the new project's folder.

There is no limit to the number of translation memories that can be used as reference in a translation project, and OmegaT makes it very easy to assign different levels of priority to these additional memories.
Translators can easily collaborate on a project.
The team functionality synchronizes the project's translation memory and main glossary between all participants, and allows easy resolution of conflicts between different translations.

section.title: A note on key shortcuts in this manual
section.para:
To avoid duplication of shortcut description, we have adopted the following notation in this manual: Single letters are used as a common name for modifiers.

section.title: Set up a new project
section.para: To start using OmegaT, first create a project to hold all your files, such as your source files, translation memories, glossaries, and eventually your translated files.
In the menu, use and enter a name for your project. Remember where you are creating the project, because you will need to return to it later.
The Create New Project dialog opens after you have named your project. At the top of that dialog, select the languages of your source and translated files, and click the OK button to continue.
If you are interested in other settings of this dialog, you can return to it any time by using to display the dialog.

Next, the dialog opens. Click on to select your source files. OmegaT will then copy the selected files to the folder of your newly created project. After the source files have loaded in the pane, you can close the dialog.

section.title: Translate your files
section.para: In the pane, OmegaT will present one segment at a time for you to translate. After you have typed the translation of a segment, use to move to the next untranslated segment. Once you leave the segment, its translation is automatically stored into the project translation memory located in the folder of the project and will be used as reference for the rest of your translation. You can manually register glossary items that you want to later use in the translation with .
See the menu for more navigation options.

When you enter a segment that matches some of the content of the project translation memories, OmegaT displays the matches in the pane. Similarly, if there are terms matching the contents of the glossaries, the terms and their translations are displayed in the pane.
Use the menu to manage translation memory matches and perform other various useful functions. Use in the menu and in the to manage glossary matches.

With , you can search the whole project for terms, sentence fragments and so on, using exact, keyword, or regular expression searches, as well as narrow the scope of the based on information such as author or date. You can also focus only on the results by filtering them in the Editor. See
for details. You can replace terms with by using a similar dialog. See for details.
You can leave notes to yourself or team members in the pane while you translate, and go back to annotated segments with or in the menu, or from the window.
The various panes give easy access to some frequently used function through a context menu. See for details. The auto-completion menu is also available in the Editor pane. See for details.

section.title: Manage your tags
section.para: If the documents you translate use bold, italics, or other decorative elements, OmegaT will convert them into tags that enclose the decorated text. Such files include LibreOffice files, HTML files, Microsoft Office files, etc. Documents will often also contain tags that have nothing to do with decorations, but are nevertheless important in the source files (and, consequently, in the translated files as well). A source sentence might look like:

example.title: Sentence with decorative formatting
example.para: OmegaT is an easy to use program for eager translators

section.para: Depending on the original format, OmegaT, however, will present this sentence in a fashion similar to this one:

example.title: How decorations are displayed in OmegaT
example.para: OmegaT is an <t0/>easy to use<t1/> program for <t2/>eager<t3/> translators

section.para: The tags in OmegaT are greyed, making them easy to recognize. They are protected to prevent you from modifying their contents, but you can delete them, enter them by hand or move them around in the target sentence. See and for details.
You can define custom tags that will be managed in the same manner. See for details. You can also define strings that OmegaT should warn you about if you leave them in a translation. See for details.

If you make mistakes when you type the formatting tags, your translated files might fail to open. Use
to validate that your tags are correct before you generate your translated files.

warning.para: If a file refuses to open in LibreOffice, Word or other application, it is often due to errors in the management of OmegaT tags. Return to OmegaT, validate the tags and recreate the translated file.

section.title: Generate the translated files
section.para: Whenever you want to see what your translation will look like in its final format, use to generate the translated documents, which will be created in the folder of your project.

note.para: You translations are always stored in the project translation memory, located in the folder of your project. Deleting the contents of the folder will never impact your translations.

section.para: Once the translated files have been created, you can open them in their original application to check their contents and eventually further modify them. Such modifications will not be reflected in OmegaT.

It is common practice to review a translation in OmegaT, with the , the function (that includes grammatical checks), as well as by making changes to the layout and options, and to then create the translated files to further review them in their original application.

Modifications made outside OmegaT can be reinserted in OmegaT (and thus in the project translation memory, to keep it up to date) either by entering them manually in the relevant segments, or by aligning the original file and the final translated file to create a new translation memory (TMX) file that will be put in the subfolder of your project folder. See for details.

warning.para: Any time you create the translated files, any previously created files with the same name will be overwritten. If you want to keep files from being overwritten, change their name after you created them, or automate the name modification with of the preferences.

section.title: A few more things to note

listitem.para: If a file does not appear into the pane, then it could be that it is in a format that doesn't work in OmegaT. See in the for a list of file formats that OmegaT can handle.
Translation projects are just folders containing files. You can create a new project for each new job, or you can add new source files to an existing project at anytime.
You can access and modify the project settings with . To see the list of files in the project, use .
Every time you create the translated files (see , above), OmegaT creates three translation memories that contain the state of the translation of the files currently in the folder.

The three files are located inside the folder and are called (project name)-level1.tmx, (project name)-level2.tmx and (project name)-omegat.tmx. They can be used as reference translation memories in other projects.
The level1 and level2 suffixes refer to the TMX standard (see TMX 1.4b Specification). You can share these files with users of other translation programs.
You can use the file with the omegat suffix in other (current or future) OmegaT translation projects as a reference translation memory simply by copying it to the folder or a new project.
For a more comprehensive introduction see OmegaT for beginners on the OmegaT web site. If you need assistance with any aspect of OmegaT, feel free to join the OmegaT user group.

section.title: Aligner
section.para: Alignment is the process of creating a bilingual translation memory from a pair of already translated monolingual documents. Aligning the contents of the files is a two-step process. First, the files are read by the aligner, which attempts to match the segments that correspond to one another in the original and translated texts. Next, the translator reviews the results and makes any necessary manual adjustments.

The aligner can read all the file formats supported by OmegaT. Select in the menu to access this tool. This brings up the Align Files dialog, where you specify the source and target languages and select the two files you want to align.

note.para: If you have a translation project open, the aligner will automatically use the languages from that project, as well the project-specific segmentation rules, if any.

section.para: Clicking the OK button in the Align Files dialog brings up the Align window, which shows the results of the automatic alignment.

The main part of the window is divided into three columns:
Keep: The segment pairs in rows that have this check box ticked are saved to the translation memory file. Unticked rows are discarded.
Source: The segments from the original text.
Target: The segments from the translated text.

section.title: Step 1: Adjust alignment parameters
section.para: In this step, the bottom part of the window presents various parameters and options you can change if the initial alignment looks like it could be improved. It also shows an Average score result for the alignment. As a rule of thumb, the lower that score, the more accurate the alignment. Changing a parameter immediately recalculates the alignment, allowing you to quickly try different combinations to obtain the best results.
The available parameters and options are:

listitem.para: Heapwise: This mode compares the documents globally.
Parsewise: This mode compares the documents segment by segment. It is only shown when it is available for the files being aligned.

ID: This mode applies to files consisting of key = value entries. This works even if the order of the keys differ in each file, and when the files have a different number of entries. It is only shown when both selected files are recognized as key=value files.
Viterbi: The default algorithms used to align the documents.
Forward-Backward: An alternative algorithm that can be used to align the documents.
There is no hard and fast rule on which algorithm you should choose. Try both, and use the one that yields the better result for your files.
Normal: The default statistical distribution used to align the documents.
Poisson: An alternative statistical distribution that can be used to align the documents.
As with the algorithms, there is no hard and fast rule on which statistical distribution you should choose. Try both and use the one that yields the better result for your files.
Character: The basic unit used to determine the size of segments in languages that do not use a space to delimit words.
Word: The basic unit used to determine the size of segments in languages that use a space to delimit words.

The aligner automatically selects the counter based on the source and target languages of files to align. It defaults to Character if at least one of the languages involved does not delimit words with spaces, and to Word otherwise. If you are working with one of each, you can try to switch between the two to see which one yields better results.
The aligner uses sentence segmentation by default. Untick the check box to use paragraph segmentation (see )
The aligner includes tags in the segments by default. Untick the check box to apply the option.
By default, the aligner highlights all numbers in the source and target segments. Untick the check box to turn off highlighting.

This option can be useful if you defined project-specific rules to match the text of the source language and need to apply similar segmentation to the target language to get better matches.

warning.para: If you modify the segmentation rules, you will be asked if you want to save those changes when you exit the aligner. The default choice is Yes, which may not be what you want if you edited the general OmegaT segmentation rules.

Example: To highlight a trademark in addition to numbers, you can change the regular expression in the dialog to \d+|<trademark>. (Replace <trademark> with the actual trademark name.)

section.para: You can also access the Highlight option and the dialog to modify the pattern from the View menu, and the other options from the Optionsmenu.

Once you are satisfied with the results of this step, click the Continue button to proceed to the next one.

section.title: Step 2: Make manual corrections
section.para: Manual adjustments are generally required after the initial automatic alignment process. This generally involves moving segments up or down to align them with the correct segments in the other language, as well as splitting or merging segments. The aligner also allows you to edit the contents of a segment, which can be useful if you notice errors such as a spelling mistake in a segment.
All available actions can be accessed from the Edit menu or by pressing the corresponding shortcut key. The most common actions are also accessible from the buttons to the right of the main pane.

note.para: The shortcut keys are well worth remembering if you use the aligner often or work on large documents, as they allow you to carry out actions very quickly.

section.para: To perform an action, select the applicable segment or block of consecutive segments. Individual segments can be selected with the mouse or the arrow keys. Segment blocks can be selected with the mouse by clicking the first segment, and holding the S key while clicking the last segment. Alternatively, you can press the Up or DownDown key while holding S to select consecutive segments. The available actions are presented below.

If only one segment is selected, the aligner will merge it with the following segment. If two or more segments are selected, they will all be merged, but remain in separate cells. Calling the command on the same selection one more time merges the contents of all selected cells into a single cell.

Use the OK button to close the dialog when finished. (In this dialog, the Enter enters a line break in the text. Use CEnter to close it wihtout using the mouse.
This command is also available from the button to the right of the main window pane.
Use this command to confirm that the alignment of the segments in the selected row or block of rows is correct. This highlights the corresponding Keep column in green.

If the corresponding segments are several rows apart, you can use this command to align them quickly. Select a segment, and press Space or select EditStart Pinpoint Align to set the first segment, and then click on the corresponding segment in the other column. (You can also use the arrow keys and press Space in the corresponding segment.)
Segments aligned with this method are automatically marked as accepted.
It can be helpful to run the Realign Pending command after using pinpoint align a few times.

section.para: After you finish aligning the two columns, click the Save TMX... button to create the translation memory.

note.para: Only rows with a ticked Keep check box in the first column are saved to the translation memory.

warning.para: The aligner does not allow you to save you work partway through an alignment. Therefore, it is recommended that you divide the files to align into shorter files that you can comfortably align in a single session. Doing so has the added benefit of reducing mismatches in the initial automatic alignment, making the manual correction step smoother.

section.para: In addition to the Save TMX... button, the bottom part of the Align windowin the manual correction step features the same Highlight check box and Pattern... button as in Step 1. This option is also accessible from the View menu.

warning.para: There is also a Reset button at the bottom of the window. Use it with caution! Clicking this button will discard all your changes and bring you back to Step 1.

section.title: Scripts
section.para: Scripts are short programs (similar to macros in office applications) that can be used to automate tasks as well as to extend or customize OmegaT functionality. They can be written by users in any language understood by the underlying Java virtual machine. OmegaT comes with a number of scripts developed by OmegaT contributors. Use the script editor to open, run, or modify scripts directly, or to write new scripts for your own use.
You can access the script editor from the command in the menu.

You can then left-click on the number to run its assigned script. You can also run an assigned script from the menu by selecting the applicable entry in the Tools menu or pressing CAF# (the F1 to F12 key corresponding to the assigned number).

section.para: By default, scripts are stored in the scripts subfolder of the OmegaT installation folder (the folder that contains the OmegaT.jar file).
New scripts added there will appear in the list of available scripts in the Scripting window.

important.para: Depending on the configuration of your operating system, you may not have permission to write to the default scripts folder location.

In such cases, you will have to copy or move the scripts subfolder to a location for which you do have write permissions, such as the , if you want to write your own scripts, add new ones, or modify existing ones.

warning.para: If you do have permission to write to the default folder, make sure you change the name, or make a backup, of any scripts you modify, as they will be overwritten when OmegaT is updated.

section.para: Additional scripts can be found here: OmegaT Scripts.

section.para: This dialog lists the available file filters. Filters used in the current project are displayed in bold. If you prefer not to use OmegaT to translate files of a certain type, you can turn off the corresponding filter by unticking its check box. OmegaT will then omit the corresponding files when loading projects, and copy them unmodified to the target folder when creating target documents. Just tick the check box to start using the filter again. Click the Restore Defaults button to reset the file filters to their default settings. If this option is checked, the source file name is not used, and alternative translations will apply in every file as long as the remaining identifying elements (previous/next segments, or a segment identifier, depending on the file format) matches.

section.title: Edit filter dialog
section.para: This dialog enables you to specify the source filename patterns for files to be processed by the filter, customize the filenames of translated files and select the encoding used for each file type when loading the source file and saving the translation. You can modify a file filter pattern either by typing directly in the fields or clicking the Edit... button. Click the Add... button to add a new file filter pattern. Adding and editing use the same dialog to define patterns. It includes a special target filename pattern editor that lets you customize how output files are named.

section.title: Source filename pattern
section.para: OmegaT attempts to select a filter based on the extension of the file loaded from the project’s source folder. More precisely, it attempts to match the source filename patterns in each filter against the filename. For example, the pattern .xhtml matches any file with the *.xhtml extension. If an appropriate filter is found, the file is assigned to it for processing. For example, by default, the XHTML filter is used to process files with the .xhtml extension. You can change or add filename patterns to specify what files are handled by an individual filter. Source filename patterns use wild card characters similar to those used in Searches. The “*” character matches zero or more characters, while the “?” character matches exactly one character. All other characters are interpreted as is. For example, if you want to have the text filter handle readme files (readme, read.me, or readme.txt) you can use the pattern read*.

section.title: Source and translated file encoding
section.para: A limited number of file formats specify a mandatory encoding. For other file formats, the encoding you specify for the extension that matches their name will be used. For example, .txt files will be loaded using the default encoding of your operating system if no other encoding is specified. You can change the source encoding for each different source filename pattern. Target files can also be written using any encoding. By default, the encoding of the translated file is the same as that of the source file. The source and target encoding fields use drop-down menus listing all supported encodings. Selecting the <auto> option leaves the choice of encoding to OmegaT, based on the criteria below.

listitem.para: OmegaT uses the encoding declaration in the source file, if present, to identify the encoding (HTML or XML based files).
OmegaT is instructed to use a mandatory encoding for certain file formats (Java properties, for example).

If you want to revert to the default filter configuration after making changes, click the Restore Defaults button. Your changes only take effect after you click the OK button to close the Edit Filter dialog. The Edit Pattern dialog offers various options. A non-exhaustive list is presented below.

listitem.para: ${filename}—The default pattern. It represents the complete filename of the source file, including the extension. Using this pattern assigns the translated file the exact same name as the source file.

${extension} —Inserts the original file extension.
${targetLocale}—Inserts the target locale code (in “xx_YY” format).
${targetLanguage}—Inserts the target language and country code together (in “xx-YY” format).
${targetLanguageCode}—Inserts only the target language code (“xx”).

See the Oracle documentation for examples of the SimpleDateFormat patterns.

section.title: Segmentation Setup
section.para: Translation memory tools work with textual units called segments. When a translation is entered, the segment containing the source text is stored with its translation in the project memory, and subsequently used to match other source segments in the project.

Not segmenting a document is equivalent to selecting paragraph segmentation. In that type of segmentation, each paragraph (as defined in the original document format) is displayed as a single segment, and the translator is free to reorganize the sentences within the segment in the translation. This setting works well with more literary or creative texts, as well as, more generally, with documents for which translation memory matches are not so important.

The use of sentences as the basis for segmentation relies on a number of rules (called segmentation rules) that define what constitutes a sentence in the source language. This setting works well with documents where repetitions or similar sentences are common, such as technical or legal documents. Pre-defined rules are provided, and the translator can use regular expressions to modify them. See in the menu.
Select the type of segmentation by clicking . in the menu and ticking or unticking the applicable check box.

section.title: Rules-based segmentation
section.para: Dependable segmentation rules are already available for many languages, so you are unlikely to have to write your own segmentation rules. However, this function can be very useful in special cases, where you can increase your productivity by fine-tuning the segmentation rules to the text to translate.

warning.para: If you change the segmentation while translating, you will have to reload the project for the new segmentation to take effect. This will split or merge some previously translated segments, which will therefore no longer be considered translated.

listitem.para: OmegaT first parses the text for structure-level segmentation. This process relies only on the structure of the source file to produce segments.

For example, text files may be segmented on line breaks, empty lines, or not at all. Files containing formatting (ODF, HTML, or other documents) are divided at block-level (paragraph) tags. Translatable object attributes in XHTML or HTML files can be extracted as separate segments.
After dividing the source file into structural units, OmegaT further divides those units into segments.

section.title: Segmentation rules
section.para: You can visualize segmentation as the process of moving the cursor along the text, on character at a time. Each time the cursor moves to the next character, rules consisting of a Before and After pattern, are checked, in order, for a match with the Before pattern on the left and the corresponding After pattern on the right. The first matching rule is applied, either by creating a new segment break at the current cursor position (for a break rule), or by moving the cursor to the next position without inserting a segment break (for an exception rule).
The two types of rules behave as follows:

listitem.para: Separates the source text into segments. For example, “Did it make sense? I was not sure.” should be split into two segments. This requires a break rule for the “?” character when it is followed by one or more spaces and a word beginning with a capital letter. To define a rule as a break rule, tick the Break/Exception check box.

Specify text combinations that should not be separated. In spite of the period, the expression "Mrs. Dalloway " should not be split in two segments, so an exception rule is necessary for Mrs (as well as Mr, Dr, prof, etc.), followed by a period. To define an exception rule, leave the Break/Exception check box unticked.

section.title: Rule priority
section.para: All segmentation rule sets for a matching language pattern are active and are applied in order of priority. Therefore, rules for specific language should be higher than default ones. For example, the rules for Canadian French (FR-CA) should be set higher than those for French (FR.*), which should themselves be higher than the Default (.*) set. Thus, when translating from Canadian French the rules for Canadian French—if any—will apply first, followed by the rules for French and lastly, by the Default rules.

section.title: Creating a new rule
section.para: Major changes to the segmentation rules should be generally avoided, especially after completing a first draft, but minor changes, such as the addition of a recognized abbreviation, can be advantageous.
Simply click on the desired set of rules in the table in the upper part of the dialog to edit or expand it. The rules for that set will appear in the bottom part of the dialog.

If you want to create an empty set of rules for a new language pattern click the Add button in the upper half of the dialog. An empty line will appear at the bottom of the table in the upper part of the dialog (you may have to scroll down to see it). Change the name of the rule set and the language pattern to the desired language and corresponding code. The syntax of the language pattern conforms to regular expression syntax. If your set of rules handles a language-country pair, we advise you to move it to the top using the Move Up button.

Add the Before and After patterns. We recommend using tools that allow you to see their effect directly to check their syntax and applicability. See Regular expressions. The existing rules always provide a good starting point.

section.title: Editor

listitem.para: You can have the source text inserted automatically into the editing field. This is useful for texts containing many trademarks or other proper nouns that must be left unchanged.

OmegaT leaves the editing field blank. This option allows you to enter the translation without the need to remove the source text, thus saving you two keystrokes ( Ctrl A and Del). Empty translations are now allowed. They are displayed as <EMPTY> in the editor pane. To create one, right-click in a segment, and select Set empty translation. The entry Remove translation in the same context menu allows you to delete the existing translation of the current segment. You achieve the same effect by clearing the target segment and pressing the Enter key.

OmegaT inserts the translation of the string most similar to the current source, if it exceeds the similarity threshold you set in this dialog. The prefix (empty by default) can be used to identify translations inserted as fuzzy matches. If you add a prefix (for instance [fuzzy]), you can easily track down those translations later to make sure they are correct.

section.para: The remaining options are described below.

varlistentry.term: Attempt to convert numbers when inserting a fuzzy match

listitem.para: If this option is checked, OmegaT attempts to convert the numbers in the fuzzy matches according to the source contents when a fuzzy match is inserted either manually or automatically. There are a number of restrictions:
The source segment and the fuzzy matches must contain the same list of numbers.
The numbers must be exactly the same between the source and the target matches.
Only integers and simple floats (using the period as a decimal character, e.g., 5.4, but not 5,4 or 54E-01) are considered.

varlistentry.term: Allow translation to be equal to source

listitem.para: The documents to translate may contain trademarks, names, or other proper nouns that will remain the same in the translated versions. There are two strategies to handle segments containing only such unchanging text.

You can decide not to translate such segments at all. OmegaT will then report these segments as not translated. This is the default approach. The alternative is to enter a translation that is identical to the source text. OmegaT can be set to recognize such entries by selecting this option.

varlistentry.term: Export the segment to text files

listitem.para: The text export function exports data from within the current OmegaT project to plain text files. The data is exported when the segment is opened. The files appear in the script subfolder of the OmegaT user files folder, and include:
The content of the segment source text (source.txt).
The content of the segment target text (target.txt).
The text that had been highlighted by the user before pressing Ctrl Shift C or selecting Edit Export Selection is selected (selection.txt).

The content of the files is overwritten either when a new segment is opened (source.txt and target.txt) or when a new selection is exported (selection.txt). The files are unformatted plain text files. The whole process can be steered and controlled via Tck/Tcl-based scripting. See Using the OmegaT text export function for specifics, examples and suggestions.

listitem.para: Ticking this check box will cause the Go To Next Untranslated Segment command to stop at each segment with more than one possible translation, irrespective of whether it has already been translated. This allows you to make sure there are no mistranslations.

Leave this option unchecked to prevent any corruption of the tags (such as a partial deletion) during editing. You can still remove a complete tag with CBackspace/Delete or by selecting it (using the mouse or CSLeft/Right key combination), and deleting it (Delete or Cx).

For example, you can enter \d+ into the field to treat all numbers as tags, enabling you to check that numbers have not been accidentally changed in the translation.
Similarly, you can use <.*?> to make sure that HTML (or similar) tags entered into the source text are preserved without modification in the translation.
You can also combine both of the above custom tags into a single expression: (<.*?>)|(\d+).

varlistentry.term: Regular expressions for fragments that should be removed from translation

section.title: Team
section.para: The name you enter here will be attached to all the segments you translate.

listitem.para: List of projects for which login details have been stored in OmegaT. Remove a project from this list if you want OmegaT to ask you for its login and a password every time you access it.
By default, stemming is used to determine the closest matches displayed in the Fuzzy Matches panel.
To obtain more literal matches closer to 100%, select the Full text, including tags and numbers option.
Determine how to handle tags in TMX files generated by other tools.
Change how fuzzy matches are displayed, through the use of pre-configured variables:

row.entry: Number of the match from 1 to 5
The source text of the match
The target text of the match
A string that shows the differences between the source and the match. Hint: use this if the text you are translating has been updated.
Same as ${diff}, but with the differences (what is to be inserted and deleted) inverted.
