Percentage calculated with the No tags and no numbers option.
Percentage calculated with the Full text, including tags and numbers option.
Indicate that this match is fuzzy (currently only for translations from PO files with the #fuzzy mark).

section.title: View
section.para: Contains various options for changing how the text or modification information is displayed.

varlistentry.term: Include the first non-unique segment when marking non-unique segments

listitem.para: Check this option to display all non-unique segments (repetitions) in light grey. If left unchecked, the second and subsequent non-unique segments are shown in grey.
Allows the user select the interval—in minutes and seconds—between automatic project saves.
Change the default interval (3 minutes) depending on the characteristics of the project:
Short intervals (minimum: 10 seconds) for projects synchronized on an internal server.
Long intervals for team projects hosted on external servers.
Specify commands to run after using the Create Translated Documents command.
An example use of this feature would be to send translated documents automatically to the client's FTP server.
By default, OmegaT does not execute commands specified in the project-specific settings (the omegat.project file), because they could have a critical impact on system security.
Only activate this option if you know what you are doing, and can trust the source of the project.

section.title: Proxy Login
section.para: If OmegaT needs to use an authenticated proxy server to access the Internet, enter the details provided by the proxy administrator here.

section.title: Secure store
section.para: This option lets you define or reset the master password used to protect login details and access keys for machine translation services. Always make a backup of that information before creating a new password, because they will all be deleted and have to be re-entered.

section.title: Plugins
section.para: This option shows a list of available plugins. Plugins are installed either in the plugins folder under the OmegaT installation folder, or in the platform-specific OmegaT configuration folder.
Additional plugins can be found on the OmegaT development site site.

section.title: Updates
section.para: Use this option to choose whether to be automatically notified of updates to OmegaT.

section.title: Pane manipulation
section.para: The main window consists of several panes, the main menu, and a status bar. You can change the position of a pane, or even undock it as a separate window, by clicking and holding its name and dragging it.

note.para: If you cannot see all panes (opened or minimized), you can use the command in the menu to restore them to their default state.

section.para: The top right corner of a pane will show different icons depending on the type of pane and its current status:

row.entry: Minimizes the pane, so that it only shows as a tab at the bottom of the window.
Restores a maximized pane to its previous layout.
Undocks the pane from the main window.
Returns the pane to the main window.

section.para: You can group panes in the same area of the window. Doing so shows a tab with the name of the panes the top of the group. Panes can be resized by dragging the separators between them. Should you lose track of the changes you made to the user interface, you can use the command in the menu any time to go back to the default layout.

section.title: Context menus
section.para: Some panes have a specific associated context menu. You can call that menu using the standard method for your OS, or with the OmegaT defined shortcuts (see for details).

section.title: Dragging and dropping
section.para: Files can be dragged and dropped on certain panes, with the following results.

listitem.para: Editor pane: Dropping an OmegaT project file (omegat.project) onto this pane will open the corresponding project will be opened after closing the currently open project, if any.
Dropping other files will copy them to the source folder. This also applies to the window.
Fuzzy Matches pane: Dropping .tmx files onto this pane will copy them to the tm folder.
Glossary pane: Dropping files with a recognized glossary extension (.txt, .tab, etc.) will copy them to the glossary folder.

section.title: Editor
section.para: This is where you type and edit your translations.
The text is split into numbered segments. You can scroll through the document and double-click on any segment to open and edit it.

listitem.para: The line in bold characters against a green background is the source text to translate.
The line below showing the cursor is where you enter the translation.

That line ends with a segment marker. In this example, (<segment 0400 ¶> is the marker, with 0400 as the number of the segment in the project and a ¶ symbol identifying that segment as the first in a paragraph.
You can make changes to any of the content that comes before the segment marker.
The line below the segment marker is a different segment in the source language that has not been translated yet.

Use or another command that moves to a new segment to:
register the segment in the project translation memory, and
enter the next segment to translate.

section.para: Depending on your editing behavior settings, entering a new segment may leave the line for translation empty, automatically enter the source text, or automatically enter the existing translation in your memory most similar to the segment to translate. See for details.

note.para: You are free to modify the Editor display to suit your workflow.

figure.title: Example of modified editor writing space

note.para: The modifications here include:

section.title: Empty translations
section.para: If you leave the translation field empty, OmegaT will treat it as untranslated and keep it in the original language when it creates the translated documents.

OmegaT is can store translations that are identical to the source text. This can be useful for documents that contain trademarks, names or other proper nouns, or sections in a third language that do not require translation. See for details.

section.title: Editor context menu
section.para: The default shortcut key to display the context menu is the Menu key on Windows and Linux, and SEsc on macOS. You can also bring up the menu by right clicking the mouse (C + click on macOS).

The Editor pane context menu offers:
Cut, Copy, Paste functions,
Go To Segment (to jump to the segment under the pointer),
Search Dictionaries (to search for the selected term in an installed dictionary),
Add Glossary Entry (equivalent to ), and other functions available from the menu.
If you have selected text and defined entries in , they will also be displayed in the menu.

section.title: Auto-completion menu
section.para: The default key shortcut to display the auto-completion menu is CSpace on Windows and Linux, and Esc on macOS.
This menu offers the auto-completion options set in .

section.title: Dragging, selecting, and overwriting
section.para: It is possible to drag text from anywhere in the main window and drop it into the active segment. Text dragged from outside the target segment is copied, while text dragged from within the segment is moved.
By default, the cursor is locked into the target text editing field, and the arrow keys cannot be used to move in the source text.
Pressing F2 unlocks the cursor and makes it possible to use the arrow keys to move in the source text (or anywhere else in the editor). This allows you to select text using the keyboard.
The cursor status (locked or unlocked) is shown at the right of the status bar. Use the same key to lock the cursor again.

By default, typing text inserts the new text after the cursor in the typing direction. If you want to overwrite the existing text, use INSERT on Windows and Linux, or F3 on macOS, to switch to overwrite mode.
The writing mode (overwrite or insert) is shown at the right of the status bar. Use the same key to switch back and forth between each mode.

section.title: Fuzzy Matches
section.para: The match viewer shows the most similar segments from your translation memories. This includes both the internal project translation memory you create in real time as you translate the project, and external memories you have imported from previous projects or received from the client or translation agency. See for details.

When you enter a segment, the first fuzzy match (the one with the highest match percentage) is automatically selected. You can press C2, 3, 4, 5 to select a different match. Obviously, this will have no effect if there is no match corresponding to the number pressed.
The selected fuzzy match is highlighted in bold, with words missing from the segment you are translating shown in blue, and adjacent words shown in green.
To use the selected match in your translation, press Cr to replace the target field with the match, or Ci to insert it at the cursor position.

The three different match percentages have the following meaning, in order:
Percentage calculated with stemming based on the source language tokenizer, and ignoring tags and numbers (generally the highest).
Percentage calculated without stemming, and still ignoring tags and numbers (generally slightly lower).
Percentage calculated on the entire text, including tags and numbers (generally the lowest).
You can change how matches are displayed or sorted. See for details.

section.title: Glossary
section.para: The Glossary pane shows the translations of terms in the current segment that are present in the glossary files located in the project's folder.
You can select a term in the glossary pane and right click on it to insert it into the translation.

If you have activated in the menu, you can right click on the highlighted word in the source segment to open a pop-up menu listing the translations available in your glossaries. Selecting one will insert it in the segment at the current cursor position.
You can use the glossary preferences to fine tune how the glossaries are displayed. See for details.
OmegaT includes one writable glossary file per project. Use in the menu to add terms to that file.
Modifications to any glossary file in the glossary folder are immediately recognized by OmegaT and displayed in the glossary pane.

section.title: Dictionary
section.para: Dictionaries refer to the electronic equivalents of the printed dictionaries, such as Merriam-Webster, Duden, or Larousse, that you might have on your desk. See for details.

section.title: Machine Translation
section.para: The machine translation pane, when opened, contains the suggestions produced by machine translation tools for the current segment. Use Cm to replace the translation of the current segment with the suggested translation.
See for details.

section.title: Multiple Translations
section.para: A given source segment may require several different translations, depending on context. If the current translation of the segment is not suitable, you can use the command in the menu to specify an alternative translation. The entered translation will then be treated as an alternative translation of the source segment.
You can define one of the alternatives—the most common or likely, for instance—as the default translation with the command.

section.title: Notes
section.para: You can add notes to the currently active segment. This lets you come back to it later to review the translation, check that alternative translations are correct, or ask colleagues for their opinion, for example. You can browse through the notes using the GoToNext Note and GoToPrevious Note commands.

section.title: Comments
section.para: Certain specialized translation or localization file formats, such as the PO format, allow the inclusion of comments to give the translator instructions or provide additional context about the segment. One example is the author of the PO file using comments to inform the translator of length limits that must be respected in the translation.

section.title: Status bar
section.para: The status bar displays workflow information at the bottom of the main window. It provides feedback on the progress of specific operations, and also displays the number of fuzzy and glossary matches for the current segment.
The counters in the lower right corner keep track of the progress of the translation. (The left-hand column uses the numbers from the above figure):

row.entry: Number of segments: translated/total for the current file
Number of unique segments: translated/total for the entire project
Total number of segments in the project (including repetitions)
Number of source and target characters in the current segment

section.para: From a practical standpoint, the second pair of numbers is the most important since it show how much you have done so far with respect to the total number of segments to translate. The project in the example is evidently finished, as all the unique segments have been translated.

You can also click on the counters to switch to a percentage-based indication of your progress. In that case, the first pair of numbers shows you the percentage of the current file that has been completed, with the number of remaining segments for that file given in parentheses. Similarly, the second pair gives you a completion percentage for the entire project, along with the number of total remaining segments in parentheses. In projects with a large number of segments of very different lengths, this can be a more useful indicator of progress than a simple segment count.

chapter.title: Project Folder
chapter.para: An OmegaT project consists of a set of folders and files that contain the resources used for translating.

A project is a folder containing, at a minimum, the following file and folder:
omegat/
This is the project subfolder that always contains , the project translation memory, and , the statistics data file for the project.
Other files will be added over the course of a translation project.
omegat.project
This file contains the properties of the project and also acts as an address bookthat specifies where project resources are located. By default, a newly created project will contain all the required resources within its folder, and those resources are assigned the default names below.
source/: the folder that contains the source files
target/: the folder where the target files are created
glossary/: the folder that contains the glossaries
glossary/glossary.txt: the project writable glossary
tm/: the folder that contains the reference translation memories
dictionary/: the folder that contains the dictionaries The information contained in the project file includes, notable, the source and target languages, their respective tokenizers, and the type of segmentation used.
You can assign locations other than the default ones to the various resources either when you create it, or later on. Note that the files in a given location will not be moved automatically if you change it after you have started working on the project. You will have to move any necessary files to the new location manually. For example you can
instruct OmegaT to create the translated files in a shared folder outside the project folder, in a location easily accessible to your reviewer, or
instruct OmegaT to use a glossary folder from a separate but related project, or
instruct OmegaT to use a reference translation memory folder that you have set up for related projects, and so on.
You can access the project folder and its subfolders with the command in the menu.
Creating a project gives it a core hierarchy, but its final structure is not fixed. You can easily remove or add files and subfolders to the project.

section.title: source
section.para: The source subfolder contains the files to translate. You can freely add or remove files from that folder at any time. You can also structure the source subfolder in any form you like. If the files to translate are contained in a tree structure (as in a website), you need only specify the top-level subfolder. OmegaT will maintain the entire contents and while keep the tree structure intact.

section.title: target
section.para: This subfolder is initially empty. It is populated when you select Cd Project Create Translated Documents . The files in the folder, whether fully translated or not, are then generated here, using the same hierarchy as in the source subfolder.

The contents of the files in the target subfolder will reflect the current state of the translation from the project translation memory saved in the current /omegat/project_save.tmx file. Untranslated segments will remain in the source language.

section.title: tm
section.para: The tm folder can contain any number of reference translation memories(TMX files). Those files can be any of the three varieties described in . Other CAT tools can also export (and import) TMX files. The best choice is, of course, to use the OmegaT-specific TMX files when possible to retain the in-line formatting in the segment.

The contents of the translation memories in the tm subfolder present suggestions for the text to translate. Any text with a translation in those files will show up in the Fuzzy Matches pane, if it is sufficiently similar to the text in the current segment.

If the source segment in one of the reference memories is identical to the text of the current segment, OmegaT acts in accordance with the settings defined in the Editor preferences dialog. With the default setting, for example, translations found in the reference memory are inserted in the corresponding segments and prefixed with [fuzzy] to enable the translator to check whether the translation is correct, and edit it as necessary.

The translation memories placed in the tm subfolder sometimes contain segments with identical source text, but different translations. The TMX files are read in the order of their names, and the segments within a file are read sequentially. This means the last segment with identical source text prevails. (Avoiding such situations is, of course, preferable, but may not be possible in the case of files obtained from external sources.)
In addition, TMX files in the tm folder compressed in the gzip format can be read by OmegaT.

section.title: tm/auto
section.para: Translations from TMX files placed in this folder are automatically inserted in matching segments without the [fuzzy] prefix, making it unnecessary to confirm these segments. This is useful if you already have one or more reliable TMX files with translations you already know are correct.

listitem.para: Put the applicable memories in the tm/auto subfolder.
Open the project. You will see that segments identical to source segments in those memories are already filled in. They will be highlighted in orange if you have checked the option in the menu.
Make and confirm a minor change anywhere in the project. This will add the translations loaded from the tm/auto subfolder to the main project_save.tmx file.

warning.para: If you remove a TMX file from tm/auto before Step 3, the translations it contains will not be retained in the project or saved in the project_save.tmx file.

section.title: tm/enforce
section.para: If you have no doubt that a given TMX contains more accurate translations than the current project_save.tmx file, put that TMX in the tm/enforce subfolder to overwrite the existing translations unconditionally.

listitem.para: Put the applicable memories in the tm/enforce subfolder.
Open the project. You will see that segments identical to source segments in those memories are already filled in.
Make and confirm a minor change anywhere in the project. This updates the project_save.tmx file.

Make a decision about the immutability of the enforced segments:
If they don't need to remain immutable to further changes, remove the TMX from tm/enforce.
If they do need to remain immutable to further changes, leave the TMX in tm/enforce.

warning.para: If you remove aTMX file from tm/enforce before Step 3, none of the enforced translations are kept.

section.title: tm/mt
section.para: The background of the active segment changes to red when a match is inserted from a TMX contained in the mt subfolder. The background is restored to normal when you leave the segment.

section.title: tm/penalty-xxx
section.para: It can be useful to distinguish between high-quality translation memories and other memories that, due to the subject matter, client, revision status, or other factors,are less reliable. The score of matches from translation memories in subfolders named penalty-xxx (where xxx is a number between 0 and 100), is decreased by an amount corresponding to the value in the name of the subfolder. For example, a 100% match in a TMX, stored in a subfolder called penalty-30 becomes a 70% match. The penalty applies to all three match percentages. Scores of 75, 80 and 90 for a match are lowered to 45, 50 and 60.

section.title: dictionary
section.para: This folder is initially empty, and is used to store any dictionaries you add to the project. See Dictionaries for more information.

section.title: glossary
section.para: This folder is initially empty. It is used to store the default writable glossary and any other glossaries you use in the project. See Glossaries for more information.

section.title: omegat
section.para: The omegat subfolder contains, at a minimum, the and files. It may also include several other files.

listitem.para: This is the most important file in the project. An empty file is automatically generated when you create a new project, and is gradually filled with the translations of the text in files located in the subfolder.

It constitutes the working translation memory of the project. Backups of this file (with a .bak extension) are regularly added to this subfolder, the beginning and end of a translation session, as well as while you work on the translation.
This is the statistics file for the whole project. It is updated each time the project is reloaded.
You can also update it with the command in the menu.
This file contains the latest project match statistics, which are generated by the command in the menu.
This file contains the latest project match statistics by file, which are generated by the command in the menu.

These files are created and used by the spellchecker. You can also create them by right clicking on a word marked as incorrect and selecting Ignore All (for words to skip during spellchecking), or Add to Dictionary (for words to accept as correct), respectively, from the context menu. If you already have a collection of words you want the spellchecker to ignore or accept, simply save them in text files with the corresponding names, and copy those files to the subfolder of your current project.
This file contains the project-specific segmentation rules.
This file contains the project-specific file filters.
This file contains the project-specific GUI settings.
This file contains the project-specific external searches.
This file is created if you manually change the order of the files in the window.

section.title: omegat.project
section.para: This files contains the project parameters defined in the Project properties dialog.

section.title: .repositories
section.para: In a team project, this folder contains a versioned copy of the project tree structure linked directly to the remote server.
You can make changes to the remote files (such as deleting or replacing them) by making your changes in this folder and using a Git or SVN client to synchronize them with the remote server.
In some operating systems, this folder is hidden by default. Turn on the option to show hidden files in your system to make it visible.

chapter.title: Configuration Folder
chapter.para: The configuration folder stores the majority of the OmegaT parameters and preferences for the user.

note.para: If anything happens to your OmegaT installation and you can't seem to fix it, close OmegaT, make a backup of the contents of the configuration folder, delete the original configuration folder, and restart OmegaT. You can then copy your backed up configuration files to restore your original preferences.
If you are recovering from a corrupt installation, you should copy the backed up files one at a time to make it easier to isolate the problem if it persists.

section.title: Configuration folder location
section.para:
The location of the configuration folder varies by system (the ~ character represents your home directory): Linux
~/.omegat macOS
~/Library/Preferences/OmegaT Windows
~\AppData\Roaming\OmegaT
You can always access the configuration folder directly from the option of the menu.

listitem.para: This file includes a number of important user preferences.
This file describes the overall OmegaT layout.
This folder contains a number of log files. The most current is OmegaT.log.

These files record various internal state and program event messages generated while OmegaT is running. If OmegaT behaves erratically, it is important to include this file, or the relevant part thereof, if you submit a bug report.
The contents of the file can also be viewed using the option in the menu.

If the applicable functions are used, this folder can contain up to three text files:
selection.txt
This file stores the currently selected text when the command in the menu is used. The text in the file is replaced each time this function is called.
source.txt
This file contains the original text from of the current segment when the option in the dialog is active. The text in the file is replaced each time a new segment is entered.
target.txt
This file contains the translated text from the current segment when the option in the dialog is active. The text in the file is replaced each time a new segment is entered.
Those three files provide as a simple way to access some OmegaT content and process it with local programs such as shell scripts.
This parameter file contains customized editor shortcuts. See for details.
This parameter file contains customized user interface shortcuts. See for details.
This parameter file contains customized file filters. See for details.
This parameter file contains customized external search parameters. See for details.
This parameter file contains customized autotext parameters. See for details.

This file contains the login information for your team project repositories.
Its contents are not encrypted.See for details.
This parameter file contains customized segmentation parameters. See for details.
This folder provides an alternative location for manually installed OmegaT extension plugins. See for details.
This folder contains your spelling dictionaries. See for details.

section.title: Setting a different configuration
section.para: You can specify a configuration folder other than the default when you start OmegaT from the command line.
Doing so will save all preferences set in the dialog to that folder, and those settings will not be available to other instances of OmegaT that use a different configuration folder. See for details.

section.title: Create a New Project
section.para: To start using OmegaT, you first have to create a project to hold all your files, such as your source files, translation memories, glossaries, and eventually your translated files. To create a new project, select New... in the Project menu (or press CSn), select a folder, and type a name for your project.

note.para: Since an OmegaT project is simply a set of folders and subfolders, you are entering the name of the folder that will hold your project. Alternatively, you can choose an existing empty folder created beforehand. Keep in mind that OmegaT cannot create a project in a folder that already contains files or subfolders.

section.para: Remember where you are creating the project, because you will need to return to it later.
The Create New Project dialog opens after you have named your project. At the top of that dialog, select the languages of your source and translated files, and click the OK button to continue.
If you are interested in other settings in this dialog, you can return to it any time by pressing CtrlE.

The Project Files dialog opens next. Click on Copy Files to Source Folder... and select your source files. OmegaT will then copy the selected files to the source subfolder of your newly created project. You can close the Project Files dialog after the source files have loaded in the Editor pane,.

section.title: Reuse Translation Memories
section.para: When a project is initially created, its main translation memory, the project_save.tmx file, is empty. It is gradually filled as your translation progresses. You can reuse existing translations to speed up this process. If a given sentence has already been translated once—correctly, of course— there is no need to retranslate it . Translation memories may also contain reference translations. Multinational legislation, such as that of the European Community, is a typical example.

When you create the target documents for a project, OmegaT also outputs three translation memories for the current files in the source folder in the root folder of your OmegaT project (see ). Those three files are named after the project followed by -level1.tmx, -level2.tmx, and -omegat.tmx. You can think of these three tmx files as export translation memories. Put another way, they constitute a bilingual export of the current content of your project.

If you want to reuse a translation memory from a previous project (because the new project is similar to the previous one, or might use terminology you have used in the past), you can also import those translation memories in your new project as input translation memories. To do so, place the translation memories you wish to use in the /tm or tm/auto subfolders of your new project. Hits from translation memories in the former are shown in the fuzzy matches viewer, while hits from translation memories in the latter are used to automatically pretranslate segments in your source text that are identical to those in the translation memories.

The tm subfolder is created under the project folder by default (e.g. ...MyProject/tm), but you can choose a different folder in the project properties dialog. This is useful if you frequently use past translation memories for projects on the same topic or for the same customer. The basic procedure is outlined below.

listitem.para: Create a folder (acting as a central repository) to hold translation memories for a particular subject or customer in a convenient location on your system.
Every time you complete a project, copy one of the three export translation memory files from the root folder of the project to your central repository.

When you start a new project on that subject, or for that customer, use the Browse button of the Translation Memory Folder setting in the dialog to select your repository folder and designate it as the translation memory folder.

note.para: Since all TMX files in the /tm folder are parsed when the project is opened, putting each and every translation memory you have at hand into your central folder could slow OmegaT down unnecessarily. Conversely, it might be a good idea to remove files that are no longer needed after you have used them to fill the project-save.tmx file.

section.title: Importing and exporting translation memories
section.para: OmegaT can import both levels1 and 2 of TMX versions 1.1 to 1.4b, enabling it to read translation memories produced by other tools. However, level 2 TMX files (which store formatting information along with the text) are not fully supported. OmegaT will still read them and display their textual content, but the quality of fuzzy matches will be somewhat lower.
OmegaT follows very strict validation procedures for loading translation memory files. If an error is found in a file, OmegaT will indicate the line number of that error within the defective file.

Some tools produce invalid TMX files under certain conditions. You will have to fix them if you want to use them as reference memories, otherwise OmegaT will report an error and fail to load them. Fixes are generally simple, and the error message provided by OmegaT will help you pinpoint the error. You can also ask the user group for advice if you have problems.

OmegaT exports both level 1 and level 2 version 1.4 TMX files. Although the level 2 export is not fully compliant with the standard, it is sufficiently close, and will generate correct matches in other translation memory tools that supporting such files. If you only need textual information (without formatting information), use the level 1 file produced by OmegaT.

section.title: Creating a translation memory specific to selected documents
section.para: In situations where a translator needs to share a TMX that contain only the text from certain specific files and excludes other content, sharing the complete ProjectName-omegat.tmx is not possible. The following procedure presents one way of doing so that is simple to follow and does endanger any of the resources in the project.

listitem.para: Create a new completely separate project in the desired language pair and give it an appropriate name. Remember that by default, the generated TMX files will include that name.
Copy the documents for which you want to create a translation memory into the source folder of this new project.
Copy the translation memories with the translations those documents above into tm/auto subfolder of the new project.

Open the project. Use CT to check for possible tag errors, and CU to find any untranslated segments. Finally, press CtrlD to create the TMX files for export along with the target documents. You can also check the contents of the latter to make sure everything worked as expected.

The TMX files in the main project folder (see above) now contain only the original and translated text, in the selected language pair, of the files you copied into the source folder. Copy them to a safe place for future reference.
Delete the project folder, or archive it outside your main working folder, to avoid accidentally reusing that project and possibly polluting future TMX files.

section.title: Sharing translation memories
section.para: For large jobs involving a team of translators, it is easier for everyone involved to share common translation memories rather than pass local versions back and forth.

OmegaT is capable of interfacing with SVN and Git, two common version control systems (VCS) that are offered under an open source license. The chosen VCS manages the entire OmegaT project folder—which means the translations memories it includes, as well as the source and other subfolders, project settings, and so on. Refer to the and sections of this chapter for more information.

section.title: Using TMX with an alternative language
section.para: Some projects may require the same source text to be translated in more than one language. For example, you may have translated a Dutch text to English. However, you also need a translation to Chinese, but you cannot find a Chinese translator who understands Dutch. You do, however, know one who understands English perfectly. In this case, you can use the NL-EN translation memory as a go-between to produce an NL to ZH translation.

To do so, create a subfolder called tmx2source in the tm subfolder, copy your NL-EN translation memory file to the newly created tm/tmx2source/ subfolder, and rename it ZH_CN.tmx to indicate the target language of the tmx. The translator will be see the English translation under the Dutch source segments, and use it to create the Chinese translation.

Important: the intermediate TMX must be renamed XX_YY.tmx, where XX_YY represents the target language for that translation memory (ZH_CN.tmxin the above example). The source languages of the project and TMX file should, of course, be identical (NL in this example). Note that only one TMX file can be used for any given language pair. If you need to use several translation memories in that pair, you will have to merge them all into a single XX_YY.tmx file.

section.title: Prevent Data Loss
section.para: Although OmegaT is a robust application, you should take precautions to guard against data loss when using it, just as with any other application. When you translate the documents in a project, OmegaT stores all your progress in the translation memory file located in the subfolder.

OmegaT also backs up the translation memory to a file called project_save.tmx.YYYYMMDDHHNN.bak in the same subfolder every time you open or reload a project. The final part of the filename is a timestamp indicating when this backup of the memory was saved, with YYYY representing the 4-digit year, MM the month, DD the day of the month, and HH and NN indicating the hours and minutes.
If you believe that you have lost translation data, follow the steps below to restore the project to the most recent backup memory, which is usually less than ten minutes old or so.

listitem.para: Close the project.
Rename the current project_save.tmx file (to project_save.tmx.tmp, for example).
Select the backup translation memory most likely to contain the data you are looking for.
Rename it project_save.tmx.
Reopen the project.

section.para: To avoid losing important data:

listitem.para: Make regular copies of the file /omegat/project_save.tmx to a backup media, such as a USB key or an external hard drive, or to a cloud service.
While you are still familiarizing yourself with OmegaT, create translated files at regular intervals to make sure they contain the latest version of your translation.

Be very cautious about making changes to the files in the folder, or to the segmentation rules, partway through a project. Modifying either source files or the segmentation rules after you have started your translation could result in OmegaT becoming unable to find a segment you have already translated.

Consult the Instant Start Guide and other sections of this manual to get started. Should you run into problems, post a message in the OmegaT user group. Do not hesitate to post in the language you are most comfortable using.

section.title: Manage right-to-left languages
section.para: The justification of source and target segments depends on the project languages. By default, left justification is used for left-to-right (LTR) languages and right justification for right-to-left (RTL) languages. You can toggle between the following three justification modes by pressing CSo:

listitem.para: Default, as defined by the language
Left
Right

section.para: Switching between modes changes both how the text is entered and displayed. Each mode can be used separately in the Editor, Fuzzy Matches, and Glossary panes by selecting the desired pane and toggling the justification mode. It can also be used in all OmegaT input fields, such as the Text Search window or the segmentation rules dialog, for example.

section.title: Mixing RTL and LTR strings in segments
section.para: You can use the default (LTR) mode to write purely RTL text. However, it is often necessary to include LTR text, such as OmegaT tags, product names that must retain their original LTR language direction, or placeholders in localization files, within an RTL document. In such cases, you must switch to RTL mode to ensure the RTL (or, more precisely, bidirectional) text is displayed correctly. Note that OmegaT shows both the source and target in the same mode. Consequently, if the source language is LTR and the target language is RTL, or vice versa, you will need to toggle back and forth between the two modes to read the source and enter the target easily.

section.title: OmegaT tags in RTL segments
section.para: OmegaT tags are LTR strings. When translating between RTL and LTR languages, correctly reading the tags from the source and entering them properly in the target may require the translator to toggle between LTR and RTL modes numerous times.

Therefore, translators are encouraged to remove style information from the original document whenever possible to limit the number of tags displayed in the editor. Validate tags (using the command) and produce translated documents regularly to catch any problems quickly. Hint: it may be simpler to translate a plain text version of the document and add any necessary styling in the relevant application at a later stage.

section.title: Creating translated RTL documents
section.para: The translated document will be created in the same display direction as the original. You will have to change the text direction of the target document in its own application.

Note that in Microsoft Word .docx files, a number of changes are made automatically:
Paragraphs, sections and tables are set to bidirectional text.
Runs (short sections of text in the same style) are set to RTL.

With some file formats, such as ODF, it is also possible to modify the settings in the source file so that they are automatically applied to the target file, eliminating the need to set them every time you open it.

section.title: Translate a PDF file
section.para: PDF files are a special case. They contain text formatting information, but such information cannot be reused by OmegaT in order to create target files. Thus, PDF files are handled as plain text files, and output files are plain text files.
If you need to reproduce text formatting (as well as other things such as drawings) in your translation, there are three ways to try:

listitem.para: Use OmegaT’s default filter (PDF input), translate, create a target file (it will be a plain text file), add relevant formatting and items manually.
Use the Iceni Infix filter. See Howto - Translating PDF files with Iceni Infix and OmegaT.
Import the source file to LibreOffice Draw, save it as an ODG file, translate, export to PDF as needed.

section.para: Note: the above information applies only to PDF files with a text layer. If you have a PDF file made of scanned pages (sometimes such files are referred to as ‘dead’ PDFs), you need to use an OCR (optical character recognition) program to recognize the text and convert it to a format that can be handled by OmegaT.

section.title: Other file formats
section.para: Other plain text or formatted text file formats suitable for processing in OmegaT may also exist.

External tools can be used to convert files to supported formats. The translated files will then need to be converted back to the original format. For example, if you have an outdated Microsoft Word version, that does not handle the ODT format, here's a round trip for Word files with the DOC extension:

listitem.para: import the file into ODF writer
save the file in ODT format
translate it into the target ODT file
load the target file in ODF writer
save the file as a DOC file

section.para: The quality of formatting of the translated file will depend on the quality of the round-trip conversion. Before proceeding with such conversions, be sure to test all options. Check the OmegaT home page for an up-to-date listing of auxiliary translation tools.

section.title: Start OmegaT from the command line
section.para: The command-line alternative allows the user to control and modify the program's behavior. Once you have defined a set of options, you can save them in a script file and launch OmegaT from that script like you would have from the default application.

section.title: A very short command line interface tutorial
section.para: The command line interface (CLI) was the only way to interact with a computer until the 80's and is now a complement to the graphical interface that we use daily. To access it, you need a "terminal window" where you will give orders to the computer with a syntax that is close to imperative verb + complements which is generally described as command + parameters. The command and the various parameters are separated by spaces and and once all the parameters are typed, the command must be sent to the computer by hitting the Enter key. The computer then executes the command modified by its parameters and displays results, error messages or other side effects on the screen where the command was sent.

note.para: On Windows, the command line interface is called the Command Prompt and is available from the Start Menu. The macOS equivalent is the Terminal application located in the Utilities folder found within the Applications main folder. On Linux, a Terminal application is usually installed by default and is available from the application menus.

section.para: To simplify our descriptions we will call the CLI window the terminal.

Once launched, the terminal requires typed text commands eventually followed by parameters and sent to the computer with the Enter key to do the equivalent of what would be done with the mouse in a graphical environment, but associating commands with various parameters also allows access to functions not available to normal graphical interaction.

The most important concept to understand when using the terminal is that the terminal knows some commands by default because it knows where to look for the application that corresponds to the command that's typed. The terminal does not know new commands by default because unless the commands correspond to applications that are located in a known location, it won't know where to look for the application to run when given a new command.
Hence, to launch OmegaT, you must give the full location of OmegaT to the terminal.

note.para:
In the terminal, the syntax for locations depends on the platform. The folder within a folder metaphor is the same as with the graphical interface but is expressed by using separators (\ on Windows, / on macOS and Linux) instead of folder icons:
on Windows
C:\Program Files\OmegaT
C: corresponds to the root of the C: disk, Program Files is a folder inside the C: disk and OmegaT is a folder inside the Program Files folder. on macOS
/Applications/OmegaT
The first / represents the disk root, Applications is a folder at the top level of the disk and OmegaT is a folder within that folder. on Linux
The syntax is the same as for macOS, but the location is different: /opt/omegat
The first / represents the disk root, opt is a folder at the top level of the disk and omegat is a folder within that folder.

section.para: To navigate the disks, the cd (Change Directory) command is used with a parameter that corresponds to the location where you want to move the terminal to.

where location is the full name of the location in which your OmegaT program - specifically, the file OmegaT.jar - is located. In practice, this command will therefore be something like this:
on Windowscd C:\ProgramFiles\OmegaT
on macOScd /Application/OmegaT/OmegaT.app/Contents/Resources/Java/ on Linuxcd /opt/omegat
This command moves the terminal to the location (folder) containing the executable OmegaT.jar file, which is in fact a parameter to the java command that will launch everything.

section.title: OmegaT terminal command syntax
section.para:
The syntax for launching OmegaT from the terminal is the following: java -jar [java parameters] OmegaT.jar [OmegaT parameters]
where
java
is the command that will take all the parameters that follow and launch OmegaT with them. -jar
is a java command parameter that asks it to run a .jar package, which OmegaT is. [java parameters]
is a list of 0 or more extra java parameters that are listed below. OmegaT.jar
is the OmegaT executable that is distributed in all the various packages and is the same regardless of the platform on which it is run. [OmegaT parameters]
is a list of 0 or more OmegaT specific parameters that are listed below.

section.title: java command parameters
section.para: A list of possible arguments is given here. For more information, use the man java command in the terminal.

listitem.para: where LL is a 2 letters language code from the ISO 639.1 list.

OmegaT will be launched with that language user interface if it is available (even partially). If the language is not available, OmegaT defaults to English regardless of the platform default language.
where CC is a 2 letters country code from the ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 list.
This parameter is used with the user interface parameter above to specify a regional dialect. If the dialect is not available, the user interface is prioritized as above.
where SIZE is a number of bytes multiple of 1024 and greater than 2mb. Append k for kilobyte, m for megabyte, g for gigabyte.
where ... is the IP address of your proxy server, if your system uses a proxy.
where ... is the port number your system uses to access the proxy server.
where ... is your private Google API key. Only available if you have signed up for the Google Translate services.
where ... is your client ID
where ... is your client secret
Only available if you have signed up for the Windows Azure Marketplace translation service. The two entries required are available in your account page under Primary account key and Customer-ID.
where ... is your Yandex Translate API key. Only available if you have signed up for a Yandex account.

section.title: OmegaT parameters
section.para:
The available OmegaT parameters are listed when you use the java -jar OmegaT.jar --help command.
General options:
-h, --help
Show usage information. no option
Launch GUI Project path only
Launch GUI and load specified project --remote-project
Download an omegat.project file from the URL given as <project path> and load the project. --no-team
Disable team project functionality. Use it if OmegaT is not to synchronize the project contents. team init LL LL
Team project initialization tool where LL are 2 letters language codes. The first LL is the source language, the second LL is the target language. --disable-project-locking
Do not attempt to lock the project's omegat.project file.
By default, under Windows, omegat.project is locked, and an error message is received when trying to open a project already opened in another instance of OmegaT. With that option, no locking occurs. --disable-location-save
Do not remember the last directory opened in the file picker. --ITokenizer=<classname> --ITokenizerTarget=<classname>
Source- or target-language tokenizer to use (overrides project settings). See OmegaT.jar/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF for valid values. --config-dir=<path>
The directory to read/write OmegaT configuration files from/to. --config-file=<path>
A Java .properties file from which to load default settings. --resource-bundle=<path>
A Java .properties file to use for interface text --mode=[console-translate|console-pseudotranslatetmx|console-align]
Specify a mode other than default (GUI). See below for details.
--mode=console-translate
In this mode, OmegaT will attempt to translate the files in the source folder with the available translation memories. This is useful to run OmegaT on a server with TMX files automatically fed to a project.
--source-pattern=<pattern>
A regex whitelist of source files to process.
Here's few typical examples:
.*\.html
All HTML files will be translated - note that since it is a regular expression, the periodmust be escaped (\.). test\.html
Only the file test.html at the root of the source folder will be translated. If there are other files named test.html in other folders, they will be ignored. dir-10\\test\.html
Only the file test.html in the folder dir-10 will be processed. Again note that the backslash is escaped as well.
See for details.
--mode=console-pseudotranslatetmx
In this mode OmegaT will create a TMX for the whole project, based on the source files only. You specify the TMX file to be created with:
--pseudotranslatetmx=<path>
The output pseudotranslated TMX file. --pseudotranslatetype=[equal|empty]
What to fill the pseudotranslated TMX with.
--mode=console-align
In this mode, OmegaT will align files found in the /source/ folder of the project with the contents found at the specified location. The resulting TMX is stored in the /omegat/ folder under the name align.tmx. Which files are used for alignment depends on if the file filter supports it. Some supported filters: ILIAS Language File, Java(TM) Resource Bundles, Key=Value Text, Magento CE Locale CSV, MoodlePHP, Mozilla DTD, Mozilla FTL, PO, RC, SubRip Subtitles, Windows Resources.
Additional parameter is required in this case, specifying the location of the target data:
--alignDir=<path>
A directory containing the translated files.
alignDir must contain a translation in the target language of the project. For instance, if the project is EN-to-FR, alignDir must contain a bundle ending with _fr. The resulting TMX is stored in the omegat folder under the name align.tmx.
Non-GUI mode options:
--quiet
Reduce output to command line stdout. --script=<path>
A script file to be executed on project events. --tag-validation=[abort|warn]
Validate tags. Abort: Exit with an error if tags invalid. Warn: Report invalid tags to stdout.

section.title: Set up a Team Project
section.para: Setting up a team project requires some knowledge of servers and the SVN or Git versioning systems. It should thus be carried out by a project manager, a project leader or a localisation engineer.
As plenty of information about SVN and Git is easily available, we won't describe how they work here, but only how OmegaT works with them.

section.title: Step 1: Create an empty project on a server

para.emphasis: Creating an empty project on a server

listitem.para: Create an SVN or Git repository on a server that will be accessible by the translators.
Create a local copy of the repository (check out with SVN, clone with Git).
Create a new, empty OmegaT project in the local repository. This can be done in two ways:
on the command line: java -jar OmegaT.jar team init [lang1] [lang2]
Add the new OmegaT project to the versioning system (add with SVN and Git)
Note: If the project was created with the command line in step 3, this step has already been done by the program.
Publish the new OmegaT project on the server (commit with SVN, commit followed by push with Git).

section.para: If the project uses specific filters and segmentation parameters, both the filters.xml and segmentation.conf files must be added to the versioning system and published on the server.

section.title: Step 2: Add files to translate and other resources
section.para: Use an SVN or Git client to add the files to translate.
This can also be done within OmegaT:

listitem.para: copy the files to the source folder

use Project
Commit Source Files

section.para: To add other resources (dictionaries, TMXs or glossaries), use an SVN or Git client.
To delete files, use an SVN or Git client.
Note that only two files are modified by OmegaT during translation:
All other files are read-only. If the translator attempts to modify them, they will go back to their original state whenever the project is opened, closed, saved or reloaded.

section.title: Step 3: Send an invitation to the translator
section.para: Once the project is set up on the server, the project manager can invite the translator to work on it in either of two different ways:

listitem.para:
sending the URL of the project and asking the translator to create a local copy with Project
Download Team Project .
sending an omegat.project file containing a reference to the URL and asking the translator to copy it into a dedicated folder and open it with OmegaT.
The reference to the URL is specified as below (here to a Git repository):

section.para: In both cases, the project manager must send the translator their ID and password to access the repository.
The Project Manager should check with the translator that the statistics are identical on both sides (server side and translator side).
If there are any differences, check that the filters.xml and segmentation.conf files are under version control.

section.title: Special case: selective sharing
section.para: The process above describes the usual case, where the project manager wants to have full control of the project and where the files (and the statistics) are identical on both sides (server side and translator side).
OmegaT team projects can also be set up in a different way, where several translators share the project_save.tmx file but not (all of) the (source) files.

In this case, the procedure is the same, but the project manager does not add (all) files to version-controlled project. Instead, the translators copy the files themselves, or add mappings to synchronize files from other locations.

The mappings can be added via the UI:
Project Properties Repository Mapping
or by editing omegat.project.

listitem.para: This can be either http (which includes https), svn, git or file.
Remote location or directory of the files to translate.
Name of the local folder or file, relative to the root of the OmegaT project.
Name of the remote folder or file, relative to the repository url.
Add patterns using wildcards (Apache Ant style): *, ?, **. Separate different patterns with a semicolon.
Example: **/excludedfolder/**;*.txt excludes files that have /excludedfolder/ in the path, and files with .txt extension.
As above.
Example: **/*.docx to add all .docx files, wherever they are located in the project, even in excluded folders
By default, all files that are not excluded are included. You only need to specify this to override some exclusions.

section.title: Example mappings
section.para: Default project mapping: <repositories> <repository type="svn" url="https://repo_for_OmegaT_team_project"> <mapping local="" repository=""/> </repository> </repositories>
All the contents of https://repo_for_OmegaT_team_project are mapped to the local OmegaT project

Mapping for projects in a subdirectory of the repository: <repositories> <repository type="svn" url="https://repo_for_All_OmegaT_team_projects"> <mapping local="" repository="En-US_DE_project"/> </repository> </repositories>
All the contents of https://repo_for_All_OmegaT_team_projects/En-US_DE_project are mapped to the local OmegaT project.

Mapping for additional sources from remote repository, with filters: <repositories> <repository type="svn" url="https://repo_for_All_OmegaT_team_project_sources"> <mapping local="source/subdir" repository=""> <excludes>**/*.bak</excludes> <includes>readme.bak</includes> </mapping> </repository> </repositories>
All the contents of https://repo_for_All_OmegaT_team_project_sources are mapped to the local OmegaT project source folder, except all *.bak files but readme.bak.

para.programlisting: Mapping for extra source files from the web: <repository type="http" url="https://github.com/omegat-org/omegat/raw/master/"> <mapping local="source/Bundle.properties" repository="src/org/omegat/Bundle.properties"/> </repository>

section.para: The remote file https://github.com/omegat-org/omegat/raw/master/src/org/omegat/Bundle.properties is mapped to the local file source/Bundle.properties.
Mapping with renaming: <repository type="http" url="https://github.com/omegat-org/omegat/raw/master/"> <mapping local="source/readme_tr.txt" repository="release/readme.txt"/> </repository>
The remote file https://github.com/omegat-org/omegat/raw/master/release/readme.txt is mapped to the local file source/readme_tr.txt.
This makes it possible to rename the file to be translated.

Local file mapping: <repository type="file" url="/home/me/myfiles"> <mapping local="source/file.txt" repository="my/file.txt"/> <mapping local="source/file2.txt" repository="some/file.txt"/> </repository>
The local file /home/me/myfiles/my/file.txt is mapped to the local file source/file.txt and /home/me/myfiles/some/file.txt is mapped to the local file source/file2.txt.
Warning: if a file does not exist, the project won't load.

You can add as many mappings as you want, but only in the context of a team project, i.e. one of the mappings includes omegat.project. This feature is intended for gathering source files, but you're not restricted to source files.

section.title: Note about omegat.project and mappings
section.para: When you create a new project and commit that to a repository, the omegat.project file doesn't contain any mapping. When you download the project, the project is converted to a team project locally and a default mapping is added.

Note that the omegat.project file in the repository is not changed automatically and still doesn't contain the mappings. When you load a project, all changes in the repository are copied to the local project, including the omegat.project file with project settings. If the file doesn't contain mappings, the existing local mappings are re-applied, and only those. All other local changes to the project are reverted. If the file does contain mappings, then local changes to mappings are lost.

section.title: Use a Team Project
section.para: OmegaT team projects must first be set up on a server.
To use a team project for the first time, follow the procedure provided by the project manager.
Once the project has been opened, translation proceeds in the same way as for a non-team project, except the following points.
Every 3 minutes (by default), the local project is synchronised with the remote repository so that the project manager or other translators can see and use translations added during that period.

The interval of 3 minutes can be changed in Options
Preferences
Saving and Output .
Whenever the project is automatically saved, but also when it is opened, closed and reloaded, only two files are actually synchronised:

listitem.para: omegat/project_save.tmx
glossary/glossary.txt

section.para: All other files will be replaced by the files in the remote repository.
To add a new source file:

copy the files to the source folder
use Project
Commit Source Files
Existing source files can be modified, but the commit operation must be carried out before an automatic save and before the project is reloaded or closed.
Files must be deleted by the project manager.

para.emphasis: Changing segmentation rules or file filters

section.para: Project parameters must be changed by the project manager.
A team project can be opened and translated offline. All the changes will be synchronised the next time a connection is available.
To work offline:

listitem.para: Disconnect from the network before opening the project,
or open the project with the command line using the --no-team option.

section.title: How to download and install dictionaries
section.para: Dictionaries in OmegaT are based on the StarDict or on the Lingvo DSL format. To install the necessary files for the StarDict format, proceed as follows:

listitem.para: Search for the required language combination - for instance on the dictionary links given by the OmegaT Wiki.
Download the file - it should be a tarball archive (extension tar.bz or tar.bz2).
Extract its contents into the dictionary project folder. There should be three files, with extensions dz, idx and ifo.

section.para: Note that in addition to "source-target" dictionaries you can, using the Dictionary feature, obtain access to information such as:

listitem.para: Webster's Revised Unabridged Dictionary (1913)
Longman Dictionary of Contemporary English
The Britannica Concise Encyclopedia
etc...

section.para: Some of the dictionaries have no strings attached - i.e. are "Free to use", and others, like the selection above, are under the GPL license.

listitem.para: Check that your dict files are in the correct folder (or in a subfolder below it). Access your dictionary folder with in the menu.
Does the folder contain three files of the same name, with extensions? If only one file is present, check its extension. If it is tar.bz, you have forgotten to unpack (untar) it.

appendix.title: Glossaries
appendix.para: Glossaries are terminology files. They can be created and updated manually or imported from other projects.
A given project can have any number of reference glossaries, but only one glossary, the project default glossary, will be directly writable from the OmegaT user interface.
Regardless of the number of glossaries in a project, any term in a segment that has a match in a glossary will be displayed in the Glossary pane.

section.title: Default glossary
section.para: The default writable glossary is located in the the glossary project folder and is called glossary.txt.
Its name and location can be modified in the project properties dialog but its extension must be .txt or .utf8 and its location must be contained in the glossary project folder.

The file does not need to exist when setting it, it will be created when adding the first glossary entry. If the file already exists, no attempt is done to verify the format or the character set of the file: the new entries will always be in tab-separated format and the file will be saved in UTF-8 encoding.

section.title: Usage
section.para: To use an existing glossary, simply place it in the glossary folder after creating the project. OmegaT automatically detects glossary files in this folder when a project is opened.

To add a new term to the writable glossary use Edit > Create Glossary Entry (Ctrl+Shift+G). Newly added terms will be immediately recognized. To add new terms to reference glossaries, edit them in an external text editor. Newly added terms will be recognized as soon as the changes have been saved.
The source term can be a multi-word term.
The glossary function uses stemming to find matches. Deactivate Use stemming for glossary entries in the OmegaT global preferences to only find exact matches for a term.

The source term is displayed before the " = " sign and the target terms after. Comments are displayed after a number and each on a separate line. Terms from the project writable glossary are displayed in bold face. Terms from the reference glossaries are displayed in normal face.
To display the Autocompletion contextual menu for the glossary matches, hit the OS dependant key (Escape for macOS, Ctrl+Space for the other platforms).

To underline matching terms in the source part of the segment use View > Mark Glossary Matches. Right-click on the underlined term and select a target term to insert it at the cursor location in the target part of the segment.

section.title: File format
section.para: OmegaT glossary files are simple plain text three-column lists with the source term in the first column, an optional target term in the second column and an optional comment in the third column.
Plain text glossaries can be "tab separated values" (TSV) files or "comma separated values" (CSV) files. A third possible format is the "TBX" (TermBase eXchange) ISO standard.
The project default writable glossary is always a TSV file saved in UTF-8 encoding.
Glossaries are read in an encoding that depends on the file extension:
Glossaries must be located in the glossary project folder. Glossaries located in nested folders are also recognized.

para.emphasis: Problem: No glossary terms are displayed - possible causes:

listitem.para: No glossary file found in the glossary folder.
The glossary file is empty.
The items are not separated with a TAB character.
The glossary file does not have the correct extension (.tab, .utf8 or .txt).
There is no EXACT match between the glossary entry and the source text in your document - for instance plurals.
The glossary file does not have the correct encoding.
There are no terms in the current segment which match any terms in the glossary.
One or more of the above problems may have been fixed, but the project has not been reloaded.

para.emphasis: Problem: In the glossary pane, some characters are not displayed properly

listitem.para: ...but the same characters are displayed properly in the Editing pane: the extension and the file encoding do not match.

appendix.title: Spell checker
appendix.para: OmegaT has a built-in spell checker based on the spelling checker used in Apache OpenOffice, LibreOffice, Firefox and Thunderbird. It is consequently able to use the huge range of free spelling dictionaries available for these applications.

section.title: Installing spelling dictionaries
section.para: Before the spell check function can be used, a suitable dictionary or dictionaries (i.e. for your target language) must be installed. To install spelling dictionaries, follow this procedure:

listitem.para: In your file manager, create a new folder in a suitable location in which to store spelling dictionaries (D:\Translations\spellcheckers in the example below).
In OmegaT, select Options > Spell Checking, then click Choose beside the Dictionary file folder field. Navigate to and select the folder you created for dictionaries.

Place the dictionary files you wish to use in this folder. There are essentially two ways in which you can do this. You can either copy files manually, i.e. from elsewhere on your system, using your file manager; or you can use OmegaT's "Install new dictionary" function to provide a list of available dictionaries to select from. Note that the "Install" function requires an Internet connection. The selected languages will then be installed and will eventually appear in your spell checker setup window (this may take a while).

section.para: Copying the files manually makes sense if you already have suitable dictionary files on your system, for instance as part of your Apache OpenOffice, LibreOffice, Firefox or Thunderbird installation. It is simpler, however, to look for dictionaries online, using the URL of online dictionaries field:
Clicking on Install new dictionary button will open the Dictionary installer window, where you can select the dictionaries you want to install.

The names of the files must correspond to the language code of your target language as defined in the project properties dialog (Project > Properties). For example, if you have selected ES-MX (Mexican Spanish) as the target language, the dictionary files must be named es_MX.dic and es_MX.aff. If you only have a standard Spanish dictionary available, with file names es_es.dic and es_es.aff for instance, you can copy these files to es_MX.dic and es_MX.aff, and the spelling dictionary will work. Note that this will of course check for the standard (Castillian) rather than for Mexican Spanish.

section.title: Using spelling dictionaries
section.para: There is no need to instruct OmegaT to use a particular spelling dictionary; OmegaT will use the correct language dictionary based upon the language codes of your project. Check however that the language codes are exactly the same: an FR-FR dictionary will not work with an FR target setting, for example. If necessary, edit the file names of the dictionary or change your project's language settings.
To enable the spell checker, select Options > Spell Checking and tick the Automatically check the spelling of text check box (see above).

Right-clicking on an underlined word (Artund in the figure above) opens a drop-down menu listing suggestions for the correction (Art und). You can also instruct the spell checker to ignore all the occurrences of the mis-spelled word, or add it to the dictionary.

section.title: Hints
section.para: If the spell checker is not working, then make sure first that the check box "Automatically check the spelling of text" in the spell checker dialog (Options > Spell checking...) is checked.

Also check that the target language code of your project against the available vocabularies in the setup window. The spell checker uses the target language code to determine the language to be used : if the target language is Brazilian Portuguese (PT_BR), the subfolder with vocabularies must contain the two vocabulary files, called pt_br.aff and pt_br.dic.

If you have already translated a large body of text, and then realize the target language code of the project does not match the spell checker's language code (you specified pt_BR as the language, but there are no pt_BR vocabularies, for instance) you can simply copy the two corresponding files and rename them (e.g. from pt_PT.aff and pt_PT.dic to pt_BR.aff and pt_BR.dic). Of course it is much wiser, to take a short break and download the correct versions of the spell checker.

Note that Remove physically removes the selected vocabularies. If they are used by some other application on your system, they will disappear from that application, too. If, for whatever reason, you need to do this from time to time, it may make sense to copy the files involved to a different folder, reserved just for use by OmegaT.

section.title: Shortcuts description in this manual
section.para: OmegaT generally does not use buttons to give you access to its functions. The functions are available from the menus and most of them have been assigned default shortcuts.
You will only need a few minutes of working with OmegaT to remember the most frequent shortcuts, and you will always be able to learn new shortcuts from the menus.
Almost all of OmegaT's shortcuts are customizable. See for details.

OmegaT runs on any platform that runs a Java Runtime Environment (Windows, macOS, Linux being the most mainstream). The modifier keys that compose the shortcuts vary slightly depending on the platform. To make reading easier we have adopted the following presentation for modifier keys:
